Articles.Content:
No, not Woodstock's friend. Apollo 10's lunar module.

https://www.skyandtelescope.com/astronomy-news/astronomers-might-have-found-apollo-10-snoopy-module/

It certainly would be interesting to bring Snoopy back to Earth. It was in Solar orbit for half of a century - what kind of damage it took from radiation, vacuum, micrometeoroids and temperature changes?
Getting it back to Earth orbit is one thing, but the surface...not many ships could bring it down.
At last they must deliver it to the Moon.

6 hours ago, Scotius said:

It certainly would be interesting to bring Snoopy back to Earth. It was in Solar orbit for half of a century - what kind of damage it took from radiation, vacuum, micrometeoroids and temperature changes?

You have satellites in orbit who is older and who is far easier to reach, the moon landing sites to more dV to reach but you could drive around with an rover and inspect stuff. 
One of the Apollo missions landed next to an probe but it was just a few years old. 

As for bringing it home, starship is the only planned ship I know about who could take it down, not sure if it would have fitted in an shuttle.
